strIntroduction: Kyoto has a large cultural legacy coming from its 1200 year-long history. We offer special private tours in Kyoto at affordable costs. Our government-licensed guides will meet you at your hotel, and take you not only to major tourists' spots but also to lesser-known alleys and markets. At the end of the tour, you will agree that the best feature of Kyoto city is the mixture of the new and the old! Sanjusangen-do ↓ Kiyomizu Temple ↓ Sannenzaka ↓ Gion ↓ Nishiki Market ↓ End of tour (Tour guide will assist you how to get to the subway station or the nearby bus stop for your next visiting spot or your hotel) ==Sanjusangen-do== The main hall of Sanjusangen-do contains 1,001 wooden statues of Juichimen- Senju- Kannon, "11-faced, thousand -armed Buddhist goddess of mercy". The principal image, the seated statue of Senju Kannon, sits in the center of the collection. These statues exhibit an extraordinary level of craftsmanship from the Kamakura period, representing the essence of Buddhist art. Although the Kannon Bodhisattvas all look almost identical, there seems to be the statue resembling yourself among them. == Kiyomizu Temple == This temple predates the foundation of Kyoto and has had millions of pilgrims ever since. It is designated as a UNESCO World Heritage site with over 30 structures, including a huge wooden veranda in front of the main hall that juts out over the cliff and provides you a panoramic view of Kyoto. There is a famous expression: that states "You must jump off the stage of Kiyomizu." It means that you should take the plunge to make your dreams come true. == Sannenzaka == This sloped path leading to Kiyomizu temple was originally paved with stones in about 808 AD and may be the most trod-upon street in Kyoto. It is lined with old wooden houses running restaurants and shops selling pottery, artworks and other traditional goods. You may come across young women dressed in kimono and feel as though you had traveled back in time to the days of 300 years ago. == Gion == Gion is an entertainment district beautifully lined with traditional town houses and restaurants, you will see encounter geiko and maiko, professional entertainers trained in traditional Japanese dance and music, including the playing the shamisen (like a three-stringed guitar) and singing. They can be seen wearing, beautiful, elaborate kimonos as they walk to and from appointments. Some Japanese entertainment, like kabuki, is performed solely by men, but in Gion, all the entertainment is provided by women. After graduating from Jr. High School, girls enter a preparatory program to become maiko, apprentices of geiko. They learn skills such as dance, music, tea ceremony and flower arrangement to become the ideal traditional entertainer. ==Nishiki Market== If you need a break from temple hopping, Nishiki Market is a great place to visit. Located in the center of the town, Nishikikoji-dori, 400 meters long, is a street lined with around 130 shops selling Kyoto's specialties, such as Kyoto vegetables, dried and pickled foods, fish, and more. That's why it is called "the kitchen of Kyoto". The variety of foods on display is staggering and the frequent cries of Irashaimase (Welcome!) are heart-warming.
strTitle: Explore Kyoto: Gion, Kiyomizu, Nishiki Market - Private Tour

strIntroduction: Come experience the high life in Ginza! Ginza is a district in Tokyo known for its many department stores, boutiques, restaurants, and coffee houses. In this activity, I will take you to the best of Ginza based on your interests. Some suggestions for your tour will include: Shopping: Ginza is a shopper's paradise with many Japanese brands and most major international brands. "Ginbura": Ginbura is a word used in japan to describe the act of walking around Ginza on the weekends when parts of its streets close to traffic. You'll also see that many street performers appear for "Ginbura". Art: There are a number of popular art galleries around the Ginza area including Galleria Grafica Tokyo, Shiseido Gallery, and Vanilla Gallery. There are also kabuki theaters and delicious upscale restaurants you might want to visit. Contact me for more information.
strTitle: Guided Tour of Ginza

strIntroduction: The Japanese kimono is one of the world’s most recognizable traditional garments. However, the kimono is extremely complex and there is a specific step-by-step process to properly put one on. The friendly professionals will assist you in trying on your kimono, making it extremely easy and hassle free. Come and try a piece of history and experience wearing a traditional kimono for yourself! After putting on your Kimono, you can walk around Ginza and show off your beautiful kimono to the world. These are the options that you can choose from: -Kimono Experience 30minutes Try wearing a kimono for fun! Bring your camera! You can go outside about 15minutes for take some pictures. -Kimono Walking 120minutes Try wearing a kimono and take a walk around Ginza! -Formal Kimono 180minutes Experience wearing Japanese wedding garments!
strTitle: Walk Around in a Kimono in Ginza, Tokyo

strIntroduction: Shinjuku is known to be a busy city, with lots of entertainment and great shopping areas! More than two million passengers use Shinjuku Station everyday, and is very lively at night, where many people go out to drink after work with their colleagues or with friends! In this tour, you will be going around places in Shinjuku that many locals go. This tour will provide you with a great opportunity for you to experience the Japanese culture! Tour Itinerary: 18:00 Meet at JR Shinjuku Station, West Exit Head towards the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building Observation Deck. -This observation deck is free to enter, and is one of Tokyo's best observation deck. You will be able to look out towards Shibuya and Odaiba, and enjoy the excellent view! -The Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building is the third tallest building in Tokyo, with an height of 243m from the base to top). Head towards Kabukicho -As we walk to Kabukicho, look up and examine the skyscrapers in Shinjuku! The rooms inside the buildings will be lit up, and would be pretty against the night sky. -Kabukicho has many bars and cinemas and is known to be a major shopping and restaurant area. The street will be bright with neon signs and will be lively with people! -You will be able to visit an arcade center with many fun games! Head towards Goldengai -Goldengai is an small area within the Kabukicho District. This narrow street is packed with bars and eateries. It is known to be a nightlife district, where many of the bars are small, only able to seat a few customers. We will be stopping by one bar or eatery. Enjoy the Japanese nightlife atmosphere as you eat delicious food! Visit Hanazono Shrine -This shrine dates back to the mid 17th century. It is one of the important Shinto Shrines in Tokyo. -The Shine has undergone many reconstructions due to fires and damage that was done during the World War II. Head towards Omoide Yokocho -Omoide Yokocho is also a narrow street that is filled with many small eateries that serve yakitori, sushi, ramen, and more! -Most eateries only have a few seats aligned in front of one counter. Enjoy the cozy atmosphere! We will also be stopping by a bar or eatery here in Omoide Yokocho! 23:00 Back to Shinjuku Station Come join this tour with us and explore the city of Shinjuku! You will have the opportunity to mingle with the locals and have a great night! Photo Credits: https://flic.kr/p/jahLgj https://flic.kr/p/jao7kN https://flic.kr/p/aAmvCD https://flic.kr/p/5JP1pX https://flic.kr/p/6cEB8G https://flic.kr/p/o3P6Qh
strTitle: Enjoy Your Night Exploring Shinjuku Kabukicho with locals!

strIntroduction: We(one of our family member) will guide you to the tea field at the top of a mountain and tell you all about the history and production of this pesticide-free organic tea which began in 1975. If the weather is nice, you can enjoy an scenic view of of Mount Fuji, Suruga Bay, Izu Peninsula and the town below from the tea field. You will stay with a family of tea farmers in their house. Dinner will comprise traditional dishes with plenty of seasonal chemical-free vegetables. Let's talk about traditional agriculture, nature, community, and the culture of Japan over dinner. On the second day, there will be tour around our tea factory in the morning. This factory started domestic tea making since the year 2000. They imported the first professional tea roller machines from Sri Lanka to produce authentic domestic tea. You will have a chance to taste several types of tea including black tea and green tea. We will also introduce the best way to make good tea for each type of tea. Time will be from 3pm to 10am of the next day. Deepen your knowledge on Japanese tea. Experience the traditional lifestyle of farmers living in organic tea production lands. *Please note that due to seasonal harvesting we won't be able to host you everyday, so please contact us before you make any reservation. Do not hestitate to send us a message too if you have further questions with regards to the tour. Thank you for your kind understanding.
strTitle: Stay in the Land of Organic Tea and Learn Tea Culture

strIntroduction: Since the Edo period (1603-1868) Asakusa has been the most popular tourist site in Tokyo. Today, Asakusa remains the No.1 destination for foreign tourists. Come join us in this private walking tour in Asakusa! Nakamise street is the oldest shopping arcade in Tokyo, and is always bustling with visitors enroute to Senso-ji Temple. Be taken back in time in Dempoin Street, where you can enjoy the atmosphere of the Edo period. Take in a ninja show at the Hanayashiki Amusement Park, or enjoy a ride on a traditional rickshaw. To really get a sense of Japanese life, why not visit a kimono shop where you will be able to try on a traditional kimono? Then take a walk in your kimono to the nearby Taiko Drum Museum. Afterwards take a rest in one of Asakusa's many delicious restaurants or browse it's souvenir shops to make this experience one you will remember. Our guide is happy to pick you up from your hotel if you book hotel pick up option, but please note all transfer expenses for this tour are excluded from the online price. You can head to the tour's departure point by taxi, or Tokyo's excellent rail system. Photo Credit: http://flic.kr/p/72zKCQ, http://flic.kr/p/aDXPcU, http://flic.kr/p/95SHj3, http://flic.kr/p/8kFc6K http://flic.kr/p/FC3Vi
strTitle: Visit Sensoji! Enjoy Asakusa Private Walking Tour!

strIntroduction: Japanese green tea is a type of tea that has a bitter taste. Green tea is often accompanied with a traditional Japanese desert as the bitterness of the tea balances the sweetness of the confectionery. This cultural combination has been enjoyed in Japan for over 1000 years, and closely relates to the preparation ceremony heavily influenced by Zen Buddhism. Come and experience the joy of this traditional duo in a Japanese tea room. Surprise your taste buds with a burst of sweetness to a surge of bitterness. (Fee includes Japanese tea and sweets)
strTitle: Enjoy Traditional Tea and Japanese Sweets in Ginza, Japan

strIntroduction: The Tsukiji Sushi Workshop is lead by veterans of the Tsukiji Fish Market and sushi masters who have been pursuing Japanese cuisine for many years in Asakusa and Tsukiji. What we at the Tsukiji Sushi Workshop are offering is aimed at people wanting to know not only how to prepare sushi, but everything from learning about the procurement of ingredients to presentation. ----------------------------------------------------- - Sushi masters profile Morita Morita-san spent 3 years in Milan gaining experience with Mediterranean seafood. In order to deepen his understanding of seafood cuisine, in 2004 he started working in Tsukiji and has been hard at work ever since. “You have to be quick here in Tsukiji. Since freshness is so important, everyone in Tsukiji gets up in the early hours before dawn and shops will start to close soon after lunch. And of course, this need for speed is one of the reasons behind the origins of sushi. We hope to share our passion for Sushi and Japanese cuisine with you!” ----------------------------------------------------- Noji At the age of 23, Noji-san started his career as a chef at the century-old Ryotei, a famous establishment of fine Japanese dining. Not completely satisfied, when he turned 33 he moved to Tsukiji to rediscover the roots of Japanese cuisine. And now, he is the owner of his own restaurant. “Tsukiji is a town of change. Adapting to both season and age, it is constantly striving to provide the perfect ingredients for cuisine. For chefs like me, it really is a treasure trove – if I come here I can get hold of ingredients I can’t get my hands on anywhere else. I look forward to sharing my experience of Tsukiji with you!” ----------------------------------------------------- On the morning of the workshop, we will come and pick you up from the local train station (Tsukiji Station, on the Tokyo Metro Hibiya Line) at 8:30 am. On a typical day, after a brief round of introductions we will show you around to the Tsukiji Inner and Outer Fish Market. Here, we will show you how to select delicious, seasonal ingredients for making sushi (in Japanese this process is called “Mekiki”, literally meaning “judgement by eye”) – and after this, under the expert guidance of our sushi chef you will finally get to try your hands at preparing sushi! At the end of it all, everyone will have the chance to savor the delicious meal you’ve just prepared. For more details about the itinerary, please check out the picture.
strTitle: Join a Tsukiji Sushi Workshop

strIntroduction: Teaching Kimono lovers how to wear a Kimono as well as sharing the Japanese tradition and culture has been my joy and pleasure. You'll be able to wear a traditional Japanese Kimono on your own in only three lessons! Lessons will be taught in my house in Meguro Tokyo, about 5 minute walk from JR Meguro station. I can teach in both Japanese and English. 1st Lesson: Nagajuban under-kimono and kimono robe 2nd Lesson: How to tie the Nagoya obi sash 3rd Lesson: How to tie the obijime belt and obiage scarf I highly recommend that you attend these lessons once in two weeks so that you have time to practice at home after each class. You are also encouraged to bring your own kimono set. However, if you don't own a kimono set, I can lend you mine or bring you Kimono shopping in the shops in Meguro or Asakusa.
strTitle: Learn to Wear a Traditional Kimono in Meguro, Tokyo

strIntroduction: The Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office is located 10 minutes from Shinjuku station by foot. Many travelers may not be aware that the night view from the building is stunningly beautiful as you are able to get a panoramic view of Tokyo's night skyline. On top of that, entry is free of charge! There are shops there selling souvenirs as well. However, Shinjuku station is so huge that even the local Japanese might get lost in the maze of buildings of exits. Only those who are extremely familiar with Shinjuku will be able to find their way around. I will guide you from Shinjuku station to The Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office. Along the way, I will introduce some famous buildings in the vicinity. When we come back to Shinjuku, I will show you around the neon‐lit streets. If you want to go shopping, or play at a game center etc, I can introduce you to some highly recommended places. An afternoon tour option is also available, but do let me know in advance. Looking forward to meeing you! Let's explore exciting Shinjuku together! Photo Credit: http://flic.kr/p/5STREW
strTitle: Enjoy an Awesome Night View of Shinjuku

strIntroduction: Japanese tattoo is now established as one of the most renowned tattoo styles, and considered a form of modern art the world over. Most images used in Japanese tattoos have meaning and purpose, and it is hard to find an artist outside of Japan with full understanding of these. I have been tattooing for over 10 years in Japan and have specifically studied the Japanese style (Irezumi). In this experience you can get a real Japanese tattoo by a Japanese tattoo artist while staying in Tokyo. (I always use a tattoo machine, rather than 'hand-poking' my tattoos) Japanese style tattoos often depict subjects covering large areas of the body and take a lot of time, but you can also get a onepoint Japanese tattoo. The price will vary according to the size, place and detail of the design. Please check the price example which is listed below. Example prices: Onepoint tattoo/business card size is around 20,000 Yen; postcard size from 30,000 Yen. A sleeve or back piece will be charged for the outline first, and then shading: a chest or half sleeve outline is 30,000 Yen, full sleeve outline 50,000 Yen, back piece outline from 50,000 Yen. Then shading is 10,000 Yen per hour. When you book you'll pay 10,000 Yen upfront through the Voyagin website. Then you can pay the rest of the balance at the studio, since the total price will depend on the size and design of your tattoo. There's no need to pay it all in advance for a big piece - you pay each time you get tattooed. Example times: A postcard size tattoo takes around 2-3 hours, and a half sleeve takes about 15-20 hours, but it varies according to detail and color. One session can be up to 8 hours. Available every day, but please message me before booking.
strTitle: Get Tattooed in Ueno, Tokyo!

strIntroduction: Wind-chimes (Furin) are one of the summer favorites and features of Japan and are often made from glass or iron. The sound of a Furin is very beautiful and makes us feel cool in summer. Enjoy blowing glass or painting the furin. “Shinohara Maruyoshi Furin” has been famous for Edo Furin (Wind-chimes of old Tokyo) since it opened in 1990. There are 2 plans available for booking. 1. Painting some decorations on the glass, Furin Painting some decorations on the glass made by “Maruyoshi”. It takes 30-60 minutes. The quality and shape of glass and sound are perfect because the glass is made by professionals. 2. Blowing glass and painting the glass made by yourself Blowing Glass and Painting on the glass made by yourself. It takes 50-80 minutes. The shape of glasses and sound is not granted, but you can make an original Furin. You will be more attached to your own Furin. Schedule : middle of September to end of November. Of course, you can take your original Furin home with you. It will be your special Japanese gift from your experience at Maruyoshi and will be an irreplaceable memory. The Furin classes are held almost everyday. (January18th and 25th are closed) Sunday: 11:00-17:00 Other dates: 10:30-18:00
strTitle: Blow a Glass Wind-Chime and Paint it in Tokyo

strIntroduction: Hello sushi lovers, it's time to learn from a master and try your hand at making your own sushi lunch. In this sushi-making class, sushi chefs from a very popular sushi restaurant in Japan will teach you how to make lovely morsels and other useful techniques and principles you must follow to be on your way to becoming a master sushi chef. Key topics which will be covered: - How to blend your rice with the correct amount of seasoning - How to cut your fish pieces appropriately - How to combine your rice with the ingredients - How to make sushi rolls with seaweed Join us for a fantastic time!
strTitle: Learn How to Make Sushi From a Professional Chef

strIntroduction: Learn how to draw a manga character and then the illustrator will draw a portrait of you. You'll be picked up at exit 11 of Tenjinbashisuji 6-chome station on Sakaisuji (brown) line, Tanimachi (violet) line or Hankyu line. The lesson will take place at a sharehouse (5 min. walking from the station). You can choose what character you would like to draw from these below. - Songoku ( Dragon Ball) - Luffy (One Piece) - Sailor Moon - Hello Kitty - Rilakkuma - Kumamon - Any other request You can learn how to draw a well balanced figure and expression as you like from a professional illustrator. This takes 30-40 minutes. Then the illustrator will draw a portrait of you. In just about 30 minutes you can get your own portrait! You can also get your portrait in a digital data format if you want to use it on a computer. You can get a different pattern from the paper one. It takes extra 30 minutes so that the illustrator can decide the design. The portrait will be sent to you after 1 week by e-mail.
strTitle: Attend a manga drawing lesson and get your manga portrait!

strIntroduction: Beer’s one of the most loved alcohols in the world today. It’s a popular alcoholic beverage that is consumed by many in Japan. On top of that, in Japan, there are real, valuable, and regional craft beers such as the “Nihee Devil” – a local beer from Okinawa - winning an award at what is known as the “Olympics for beer”, the 2006 Beer World Cup. In this activity, you’ll be able to have one serving of beer out of 70 different types of beer barrels plus one dish at a bar called “Popye”. You can choose from the following courses: • Course for one - 2 dishes and 2 drinks of your choice • Course for two - 3 dishes, one drink of your choice, and a beer tower. Come find your favorite beer at this rare bar that carries so many different types of thirst-quenching beers.
strTitle: Drink Craft Beer at a Locally Famous Beer Pub in Tokyo

strIntroduction: The photo session lasts from 1.5 to 2.5 hours, depending on your selected plans and options. Please come to our Kimono Photo Studio, 1 minute away from Meguro Station. STEP1 Reception At the reception, we will go over your selected plan in detail, help you pick out your kimono, and explain to you all of your options. STEP2 Preparation and Kimono Experience We will help to dress you in your beautiful kimono and arrange your hair in a natural way with Japanese hair accessories. (Optional services by a professional hair dresser and make-up artist can also be arranged per your request.) STEP3 Portrait Sitting Enjoy your photo session with authentic Japanese Kimono! After the photo session, we will help you change back into your own outfit. STEP4 Photo selection Choose your favorite poses on the monitor for printing and data saving according to your selected plan. We will serve you Japanese green tea. Please enjoy Japanese culture and hospitality. STEP5 End of Photo Shoot Your photos and data CD-R will be provided to you right-away. ※The image data from your photo session will be destroyed after 2 weeks to protect your privacy.
strTitle: Experience Authentic Kimono Makeover and Photo Session

strIntroduction: ***To book on a weekday, click "Contact the Host" and message us with your preferred date*** Hello friends! Got no plan for the last day? Create your own lovely Japanese home decor to bring home!! A professional tole painting teacher, Fukuko is going to teach how to make a Japanese-style home decor at a lovely, cozy art room in the good old east side of Tokyo. In this lesson, you will learn - How to draw basic Japanese patterns on the wooden item (rabbit/gold fish) - How to write your name or your favorite English word in Japanese and also add it to the decor The cost of materials are all included! You can take it home on that day. This decor can also be hanged on the wall. The background pattern will not be hand painted, but a pasted Japanese fabric. (You can choose one from a various selection of fabrics we have!) This is a fun, creative activity! Join us and let's have a great time making a decor together! :)
strTitle: Create your own unique souvenirs: Japanese home decor

strIntroduction: Perhaps you've had "Hi-chew" or "chocoball" or any of the mouth-watering snacks Morinaga Company makes. Have you ever wondered how they're made though? If you answered yes, here's your chance to see and visit their factory! The factory you'll be visiting, Morinaga, has constantly been on the cutting edge of candy production. They make over a 1000 types of candy, extending from biscuits to chocolates. It's really an experience to see the variety of machines they use to make all this. The technology and thought behind all their products is incredible - it is a must-see. Tour Itinerary 1. You will see the short movie about the Morinaga company (20 minutes) 2. You will visit the factory (60 minutes) 3. You can buy all Morinaga snacks at the snack shop in the Morinaga factory (free time) Tour Times - 9:00 - 10:00 - 13:00 - 14:00 This tour is conducted in Japanese, but we will provide an interpreter for you. Please note that children under 4 are not allowed to enter the factory. Come and see the process of candy production! Taste the Candy! Enjoy the experience!
strTitle: Visit the Famous Morinaga Candy Factory in Japan

strIntroduction: Hakone area is one of the best places to take panorama pictures of Mt Fuji. Furthermore the area has plenty of great sightseeing spots that are worth a day trip from Tokyo. In this private guided day tour you will ride the Romance Car train from Shinjuku Station to Hakone Yumoto - a former post town - and will first see the historical Hakone Checkpoint which served an important role along the old Tokaido road between Tokyo and Kyoto during the Edo period. Then you will visit the nearby Onshi-Hakone Park near Lake Ashi which provides a fantastic view of Mt Fuji and the surrounding mountain slopes. After lunch, you will be able to enjoy the works of acclaimed artists at the the elegant Narukawa Art Museum which exhibits traditional Japanese art pictures. Finally, you will enter the dense forests to discover the mystical beauty of the sacred Hakone Shrine, before going back to the town for last minute souvenir shopping along the Hot Spring Street and returning back to Tokyo with the Romance Car train.
strTitle: Explore Hakone's beautiful spots in a Private Tour

strIntroduction: Meet Japan's or perhaps the world's last samurai in Kyoto! Compared to the one you may have seen in the movie "The Last Samurai", this one is the real deal. If you are interested in learning the art of Bushido and having a chilled-out night after the show, this tour is definitely the right choice for you! Joe Okada, also known as the last samurai, is one of world's best known sword entertainers. Not only that, but he is also the eldest licensed English-speaking guide in Japan! He will gladly speak with you about the art of samurai. This is the schedule for the activity: 6:00 pm~ The theatre opens with 1 welcome drink. Enjoy the evening samurai show at the samurai theatre, then watch the master flaunting his 53 years of samurai experience. 7:00 pm~ Q&A Time + Sword Demonstration. 7:30pm~ After the show,Samurai Bar will open.Joe will be your delightful host and serves you local food and drink for 1 hour. Check Samurai Okada's availability (schedules are subject to Joe's availability)
strTitle: Watch an Evening Samurai show in Kyoto with The Last Samurai

strIntroduction: The "sado" tea ceremony is one of the most interesting traditional arts in Japan. You can learn some local customs and Japanese manners through participating in this ceremony, where you will become knowledgeable in "Omotenashi" (Japanese consideration and hospitality). On this tour, we will pick you up at your hotel. We'll then treat you to some tea, before leading you into the the Tatami room. There, you will receive a lecture to learn how to drink tea and eat Japanese sweets in the proper manner. We can't speak very good English but are looking forward to meeting you and sharing our unique tradition through this cultural exchange. Join us! [Photo by] http://www.flickr.com/photos/rumpleteaser/6088620400/
strTitle: Learn Japanese Manners through a Tea Ceremony in Tokyo

strIntroduction: The cuisine of Okinawa is famous for the variety that is offers. Our guide will take you the local restaurants to try soba, tempura, truly delicious sweets, and more! The experience is completely flexible based on the types of places you'd like to visit and the type of food you would like to try! Coffee: We will start your adventure by having a relaxing coffee. Then we will take you a restaurant for lunch or dinner. Lunch or Dinner: We will have lunch or dinner at one of our recommended restaurants based on your preferences! Try delicious Okinawan cuisine popular among and known by local people with me!
strTitle: Explore Okinawa with Local People

strIntroduction: In this activity, I will construct a custom itinerary based on your interests. Some of the highlights in Asakusa include: Sensoji Temple: the oldest and most famous temple in Tokyo. Sensoji temple was originally built in 628 and is the best place to participate in ritual Buddhist ceremonies in Tokyo. It has a nice shopping street leading up to it with a variety of gifts, crafts, and food. Coffee houses such as the popular Cafe de Royal that produces its beans in-house and has been featured on both the NHK morning drama and the highly popular Japanese TV show called "Dochi no Ryori Show". Places to drink such as the Jazz Bar Soultrane, Sake no Daimasu, and the Asahi Brewery. I'll help you enjoy Asakusa to its fullest!
strTitle: Tour Asakusa with a Professional Guide

strIntroduction: At a Japanese tea room, guests will learn the basic terms, utensils and customs associated with the art of Japanese Tea Ceremony. Then you will enjoy eating classic Japanese sweets and drinking Matcha (powdered green tea) which the instructor skillfully serves. Finally you will try to make tea with the instructor's guidance. Through this process, in a very refined space, guests explore the origin of Japanese aesthetics, sensing"wabi", "sabi", and genuine, gracious hospitality.
strTitle: Take Part in a Private Tea Ceremony with Guide in Tokyo

strIntroduction: Mt. Fuji is the most prominent, highest mountain in Japan. It was registered as a World Heritage Cite in 2013, and its beauty and wonder has been admired not only by the Japanese, but from people all over the world. Who wouldn't want to miss the opportunity of seeing this beautiful national treasure while staying in Japan? In this tour, you will not be climbing Mt. Fuji, but you will be enjoying its view from the lake surrounding the mountain. This will be a perfect tour for you if you wish to go sightseeing while enjoying the view of Mt. Fuji and the extensive lakes around the mountain. You will enjoy the nature and the view from Lake Kawaguchi, Oshino Hakkai, and Lake Yamanaka, which are beautiful places to see the mountain. You will surely enjoy the reflection of Mt. Fuji on the clear water of the lakes. You do not have to bring heavy coats and trekking sticks to this trip, but please be sure to wear comfortable shoes and to bring a light jacket as it will be a long walk, and the weather can change throughout the day. Please be punctual due to the departure time of the buses, and please note that this tour does not include lunch. We look forward to seeing you at our tour! [Schedule] 5:40am Meet up at Shinjuku 6:00am~ Leave Shinjuku Station ~7:49am Arrive at Lake Kawaguchi 8:00am ~9:10am Hiking 9:10am ~ 11:40am Walk to Oshino Hakkai 11:40am ~1:10pm Walk around Oshino Hakkai 1:10pm ~2:00pm Lunch break 2:00pm ~ 3:40pm Walk to Lake Yamanaka 3:40pm ~ 5:20pm Walk around Lake Yamanaka 5:37pm~ Leave Lake Yamanaka by bus ~7:55pm Arrive at Shinjuku
strTitle: Best Views from Lake Kawaguchi! Private Mt.Fuji Hiking Tour

strIntroduction: Explore Osaka Central Wholesale Market with our government licensed guide. After enjoying shopping various fish including fresh tuna at the market, you will be invited to a private house and then have a chance to learn how to make three kinds of sushi. Osaka Fish Market Walk: Osaka Wholesale Market, the market dealing fresh food and products for Osaka residents, was originally begun around the 16th century when Osaka Castle was built. Since its foundation, the market has been prosperous as 'The Country's Kitchen'. This year it celebrates the 80th anniversary of its foundation, with an area that is 8 times that of Koshien Baseball Park, 320,000 ㎡, making it one of the largest wholesale food markets in Japan. When it dawns, several thousands tons of food stuffs from all over Japan and from abroad, are dealt within around 2 hours. Our government licensed guide will escort participants around market, safely in a small group, mainly looking over the fish market which has 180 intermediate wholesalers to handle fresh fish. Outside the market, the shops which sell vegetables, fruit, pickles and other ingredients can be visited if you like. After purchasing tuna and other ingredients, participants will visit a private residence. The guide will give you information about Japanese culture and everyday life in Osaka during transfer by public transportation. Sushi Making at Home: The sushi making will be explained and instructed easily and clearly by the guide who is well acquainted with sushi-making. Learn to prepare "maki sushi"(rolled sushi), "gunkan maki"(sushi rice wrapped with a strip of seaweed and topped with soft ingredients) and "nigiri sushi"(sushi rice topped with a slice of raw fish). The beautiful sushi designs created are sure to delight and appeal to guests of all ages, especially children. The sushi making at a typical private home will surely be an once-in-a lifetime Japanese experience and a great opportunity to experience and enjoy daily life in Osaka, which includes Osaka dialects with lively atmosphere! Sushi Party: After making sushi and arranging them beautifully, it's time for a sushi party and to enjoy eating together. Following the tour, participants may take with them the utensils used in the cooking lesson. Impress your family and friends with your new sushi making skills by throwing a sushi party at home – the perfect Japanese souvenir! Our guide will take you to the nearest station in order to provide the customer an easy access to the hotel or to the next destination. Photo by http://www.flickr.com/photos/stewart/2473047026/
strTitle: Private Fish Market Walking and Sushi making in Osaka

strIntroduction: Bonsai is truly a relaxing and fascinating hobby that gives you an opportunity to develop a greater connection with nature. As a tourist visiting Japan, this bonsai expedition can be your gateway to a relaxing and exciting experience that is tailored to your personal needs. Whether you're a first-timer or an avid bonsai aficionado, this is your chance to get into the mysterious and fascinating Bonsai world with a well-known and knowledgeable teacher as well as an English guide. From beginners to experts, bonsai fanatics can expect a thorough and insightful lecture in this tour. Aside from getting an extensive lecture, bonsai lovers will also pay a visit to Bonsai Museum, where lots of people around the world drop by to admire the beautiful Bonsais as well as enjoy the wonderful scenery of its awe-inspiring Japanese garden. So, what you are waiting for? Enjoy learning amazing Bonsai culture now! strIntroduction: Get a hands on experience in the process and learn about the traditional Japanese dessert, called Wagashi. Here you will visit a family run shop that has been in operation for more than 140 years! Okinaya is a sweets shop that specializes in the preparation of exquisite and graceful Wagashi reflecting the seasonal beauty and splendid culture of Japan. Founded in 1865, Okinaya is dedicated to producing and selling Wagashi for traditional tea ceremonies, gifts, and for home use. The shop was burned down during an air raid during World War II, but emerged from the devastation and resumed their business in the same location, providing the comfort Wagashi brings to people. The shop has served their sweets to many people from different walks of life including; Ayu-gashi, a signature sweet of Gifu Ukai (known for cormorant fishing), and several times for the Emperor and the Imperial Family when Their Majesties visited Gifu. The current President of Okinaya, Masanao Hayashi, is the 5th generation owner of the shop. In this program you can... 1. Learn about the history and cultural importance of Wagashi in Japan. 2. Get a hands on experience of the final processes of making 3 kinds of sweets.
strTitle: Experience the World of Wagashi

strIntroduction: First come first serve! We will give 50% discount to the first 5 reservations made! ----------------------------- Have you ever wondered how people make pearl necklaces? Have you ever wanted to make your own pearl necklace? There are many shops that sell pearl necklaces but there are rarely any shops where you can experience making your own, original necklace! Every pearl has its own distinct shape and color. You will be picking pearls of your choice and will be piecing them together! You will have your original necklace made with your favorite color and design! We have many visitors to our showroom from Japan and abroad, and we can accommodate up to 10 people at once, so we invite you to bring your friends! You can make necklaces with Akoya pearls or with Freshwater pearls. In addition to this collection, we have several other kinds of pearls. The Akoya pearl size is approximately 6 mm to 8 mm, which is a cute and lovely size. Its soft, pink color will brighten up your skin. The Tahitian Black pearl is also popular amongst our customers. It's deep black color, will give you an elegant and exclusive impression. Choose the pearl you want! We want you to feel relaxed in our showroom, and we hope you will make your necklace with ease, with our pearl necklace supporters around. Our experts are all qualified and are more than happy to show you how to make a beautiful pearl necklace. The president of this company has been devoting his life to pearls for over 30 years. If you have any questions or any troubles about pearls, please let us know! Come make your own pearl necklace with us! We look forward to seeing you!

strIntroduction: In this experience, you will be able to dress in the colorful and unique costume of Ohara women and have a tour in the area. Ohara is a rural town nestled in the mountains of northern Kyoto, about an hour from Kyoto Station, but still technically located within Kyoto's city limits. The town is best known for Sanzenin Temple and particularly popular in mid November during autumn, as the leaves change their colours, which typically occurs about one week earlier than in central Kyoto. In this activity you can wear this traditional costume and explore in Ohara City. Actual rental fee is 2000JPY per person. Photo URLs http://voyag.in/1dN5APQ http://voyag.in/19eshoE http://voyag.in/1cWcI7E http://voyag.in/19eskRi http://voyag.in/1cQSPio
strTitle: Dress Like an Ohara Woman and Tour Ohara in Kyoto

strIntroduction: Have you ever heard ''Shukubo''? Shukubo refers to the experience of staying in a temple for visitors. For a long time, only worshipers or people training used Shukubo as it was not a well-known activity. However, since the advancement of our transportation system, people started to stay in Shukubo as a experience. Shukubo is now commonly used for student trips or for foreigners who visit Japan. You might think it's hard to stay in Shukubo because it's temple, but you don't need to worry. The rooms are air-conditioned so you will feel comfortable, and you are free to roam the inside of the temple to experience the Japanese Zen atmosphere for yourself. Please feel free to join a religious service during your stay, available early every morning. You also have the option of having breakfast in the temple if you want to try eating food from the temple. We will take care of your stay, please visit us and enjoy your stay in a Japanese Zen temple! Q.Is it possible to stay 2 nights and leave luggage during the day? A.You can leave your luggage if you would stay more than 2 nights. Q.Where is the temple located? A.You can go to the temple from Kyoto station by train for ten minutes. Photo Credit: http://flic.kr/p/7EdzmS http://flic.kr/p/7Rqcs http://flic.kr/p/NCSv8 http://flic.kr/p/uTgGW http://flic.kr/p/7Rq8x http://flic.kr/p/654MZR
strTitle: Stay in a Japanese Monastery, Experience Shukubo

strIntroduction: In this activity designed for beginners, you will learn how to dye and draw using a traditional Japanese method called "Yuzen-zomé" on a handkerchief or coaster. Your instructor is Kiichiro Fujiki, who has been a Yuzen dyer for 55 years and now collaborates with Disney on projects. He has also dyed and designed many delicate but vibrant kimonos for films. To give you a brief history of the craft, "Yuzen-zomé" was originally started by Yuzensai Miyazaki about 300 years ago in Kyoto. The beautiful and elaborate Yuzen-dyed kimonos were a colorful element of Geisha culture during the Edo era. Today, "Yuzen-zomé" is still very popular and is sought after by many people. In this beginner's course, you will be able to make your own handkerchief or coaster. You can use your favorite colors to express yourself. -- All finished products will serve as your souvenir of this unique experience.
strTitle: Experience the Traditional Way of Dyeing Fabric in Tokyo

strIntroduction: Come join us on the cruise ship that sails around Tokyo Bay as you enjoy the scenery that can only be seen from the sea! For over 60 years, Tokyo Bay Nouryousen has been hosting a summer night cruise ship around Tokyo Bay for people to enjoy the summer weather in Japan while enjoying the various views from the cruise ship. This cruise ship will provide you with an experience that you will not be able to normally experience. Within the two hours you will be onboard, you will see many of Tokyo's famous sightseeing spots that will be lit up against the night sky. Why not do something different in Tokyo for one night and spend an amazing night on a big cruise ship with your family and friends? Some of the famous sightseeing spots you will be able to see from the cruise ship would be Tokyo Tower, Tokyo Sky Tree, Rainbow Bridge, Haneda Airport and Odaiba. You may be able to see the fireworks that are fired from Tokyo Disney Resort at around 20:30. The price includes an all you can drink service and the boarding fee. Other than the drinks that are served onboard, you can purchase food tickets, in which you can exchange for food (sweets, yakitori, sushi..etc) at different booths on the ship. A DJ will be playing music, and there are also fun events that change everyday! You will also get to see live performances of the Yukata dancers and get to dance along! This event will be held during July 1st, 2015 to September 30th, 2015. The cruise ship will depart from Takeshiba terminal at 19:15. Takeshiba terminal is located approximately 7 minutes away from JR Hamamatsu-cho Station (North exit) by walk, and a 1 minute walk from Takeshiba station. The cruise ship will depart as usual on rainy days, and you will still be able to enjoy the ride as there are many events that are held indoors. We will make a reservation for you a month before your desired boarding date. We will not be able to make a reservation three days before your desired boarding date. Please note that your desired boarding date may be full, as this event is very popular. -Process until you get on board- Once we complete your reservation, we will issue your tickets for the ship and will deliver them to your hotel (or you can pick them up from our office). On the day, head to the ticket counter at the Takeshiba terminal with your registration number or ticket and exchange it with the boarding ticket. The ticket counter will open at 17:00. At 18:50, you can start boarding on the ship. At 19:15, the cruise ship will leave and you will be exploring the beautiful city of Tokyo at night. The cruise ship will arrive back at the terminal at 21:00. Enjoy your ride on the cruise ship with us, as we will make this an unforgettable night for you, your family and friends! ※Please note that this event is until the end of September. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ※ Important Ticket Delivery & Pickup Information - Please Read Carefully ※ 1. Ticket Delivery We will deliver your tickets to your hotel in advance for your concierge to hold for you. The tickets will be available upon check-in. strIntroduction: Buddhist Zen meditation, or Zazen, is a type of meditation that calms the body and mind, and helps one gain enlightenment. Gifu Zenko-ji temple was founded in 1582 and was used to enshrine Japan's first Buddha statue from China. This statue, called Ikko Sanzon Amida Nyorai, was the symbol of Shinshu Zenko-ji temple and was worshiped by people from all walks of life due to its auspiciousness. During the Warring States Period (1493 - 1590), each feudal warlord scrambled to own this statue, either to protect their land or to symbolize their power. One of these warlords was Oda Nobunaga, who almost unified Japan during this warring period. When he conquered Gifu Castle, he brought this statue along to Gifu to pray for the peace of the town. After his death, the state changed hands among several warlords before returning to Shinshu Zenko-ji. Years later, the Zenko-ji hall was established to commemorate Shinshu Zenko-ji Nyorai. In this tour, you will: -Learn the proper procedures when visiting a temple -Practice zen meditation -Understand Japanese history and culture -Increase your concentration and relief stress & anxiety.
strTitle: Practice Zazen at Zenko-ji Temple in Gifu

strIntroduction: On this experience, learn about and go shopping for authentic Japanese pottery! Nagara Tobo Ceramics was established in 2003 by the Master Potter, Shinji Majita. Specializing in Minoyaki style pottery, he has inherited and maintains the traditional techniques such as Shino and Oribe. The Master creates products ranging from ceramics for daily use (including bowls and cups) to traditional tea utensils and flower vases. In this program, you can... ・ Get a detailed explanation in Japanese pottery and how Minoyaki is crafted. ・ Go and enjoy shopping! (Mino-yaki style pottery is one of the best Gifu souvenirs).
strTitle: Learn about Minoyaki Pottery

strIntroduction: Welcome to Samurai Town, Kamakura. In the 12th century, Japan’s first full-fledged military government was established in Kamakura. Still now you can feel samurai power at its historic sites, such as the magnificent Tsurugaoka Hachiman Shrine, Hasedera temple (noted for a wide variety of flowers) and the Great Buddha.! You’ll be walking quite a bit, so we recommend you wear a comfortable pair of walking shoes. We will also explore and eat the lunch on the Komachi street. The lunch is not included in this tour.
strTitle: Samurai City Kamakura Tour

strIntroduction: In Japan, we mainly eat rice as a staple. You already know that Japan has some of the finest dishes to offer; so why not enjoy them with "SPECIAL RICE" made from a strict japanese selection !? In this activity we will prepare a buffet serving “Earthen pot Rice” and “Side Dishes”. “Earthen pot Rice” is very very delicious, highly unlike ordinary rice. You will put delicious side dishes on top of the rice, too. I am sure that we can find “Otomo” (side dishes) suiting you best . ^ ^ After the meal, let's enjoy each others company and some sake. The Japanese sake is also handpicked by us. We are waiting for you guys !!! Let's eat so yummy rice with us ! strTitle: Let's eat Japanese food with "Earthen pot Rice" in Tokyo

strIntroduction: Get the best of Tokyo in a single day Don’t have enough time to travel around all of Tokyo? Don’t worry! Our 1-day tours are made for people like you who don’t have enough time to travel but would like to enjoy as much of Tokyo as possible. This tour covers many major tourist spots. After you join our West & East tour, you can say you visit most of all tourist spots in Tokyo!! We can arrange the itinerary as you like. ■ Asakusa ■ We start with the most popular tourist area, Asakusa. Asakusa is one of the most traditional places in all of Tokyo. Walking though the ancestral Japanese atmosphere you might be surprised at how Japanese religious customs are available to anyone and how Japanese time-honored manners have matured. You’ll experience the proper way to visit the temple & shrine, how to purify yourself, how to pray, and what a Japanese fortune teller is like. You will also see the new symbol of Japan’s state-of-the-art construction and architecture, Tokyo Sky Tree. ■ To the East side of Tokyo ■ We’ll have a 35-minute river cruise from Asakusa to the Japanese Traditional garden of Hamarikyu. It’s a typical Japanese style garden with a pond in center. You can enjoy the gap between beautiful seasonal flowers, tranquil atmosphere and surrounding modern high-rise buildings. At a teahouse on the pond, you can taste matcha tea with sweets if you like. 10-minute walk takes you to Tsukiji fish market, and we’ll have lunch in the outer market. You can enjoy the best sushi in the world at reasonable prices. We’ll visit another temple, Tsukiji Honganji which was built in old Indian style. Then we'll take the subway to Nijubashi, the bridge of the Imperial Palace. We’ll explain to you about the Japanese Imperial family. Finally we’ll move to Yurakucho area which is filled with local business persons by walk. You can enjoy its cozy atmosphere. As this tour finishes at near the Yurakucho station, you can enjoy shopping at nearby Ginza or have a drink at one of taverns of Yakitori alley after the tour. ★On this tour we cover This tour includes Asakusa walking tour. ■ Asakusa ■ Kaminarimon gate ■ Nakamise shopping street ■ Sensoji temple and Asakusa shrine If you already took part in our Asakusa walking tour, we will arrange a special tour to Kappabashi instead. ■ Hamarikyu ■ Tsukiji Fish Market (Lunch) ■ Imperial Palace ■ Yurackucho ■ Yakitori Alley (final stop) We can also talk about the traditional tea ceremony and the Japanese Imperial family system.
strTitle: Private East Tokyo One Day Tour

strIntroduction: Kimono is a form of traditional clothing in Japan and has the effect of making a woman look truly beautiful. Yet because kimonos are made with delicate and beautiful fabric, they are often too expensive to buy. strIntroduction: Osaka is a huge city that traditionally was for merchants and traders. Trading is at the roots of this city, so naturally a trip here should include some shopping! You can make some fun purchases while also seeing crazy and unique symbols. We welcome you to hang out in Osaka with us! strIntroduction: In this activity, we'll go on a private journey to "Kappa-bashi" where you'll find many cooking utensils unique to Japan and then to an "Izakaya" (Japanese bar) for dinner. Have you heard of Kappa-bashi before? It's the biggest market for cooking utensils in Japan. The goods come from other countries as well and adds to the variety which includes food replicas. After you enjoy Kappa-bashi, we move to Izakaya in Asakusa or Ueno. At an Izakaya you'll find a variety of food and drinks that are unique as well as affordable. Having traveled to many countries myself, I can guarantee you that food in Japan is diverse because it includes many foreign dishes such as Yakiniku (BBQ) from Korea, curry from India, and Ramen( Noodle) from China. Japan has also adapted foreign recipes and created its own orignial dishes. Join me for a great night! photo by: http://www.flickr.com/photos/hikosaemon/5714957697/ http://www.flickr.com/photos/hikosaemon/5464297804/
strTitle: Private Kappa-bashi and Izakaya Experience in Tokyo

strIntroduction: Kamakura is a famous tourist spot and a short trip from Tokyo. It is located less than an hour south of Tokyo by train. There are many zen temples and shrines surrounded by great natural areas. I can assist your kamakura trip to make it more fun and easier than traveling alone. There are many Japanese tourists, many complicated buses, but you will have an easier time traveling with me. There are many highlights in Kamakura! Some examples: ・Walk around famous zen temples in Kita Kamakura ・Visit the world-famous Great Buddha ・Walk a hiking course ・Visit Kirido-shi(Old path) ・Attend Zazen meditation (as the situation allows) ・Try Syakyo (as the situation allows) I can arrange the tour based on your request. strIntroduction: As the old saying goes, a picture is worth a thousand words. This activity will make your trip to Tokyo even more memorable with your very own hand-made mini album of unforgettable moments! The host will meet you at Azabujuban station/the studio. In this 2-hour workshop, you will learn how to combine images with words, and get ideas and inspiration on how to collect and organize your scraps in a creative way! If you have any memorable paper items collected during your trip (e.g. used train tickets, paper packages, photos etc), please bring them along for the workshop. But don't worry even if you don't have any. What can you make? You will learn several book binding techniques such as Japanese stab binding, Star book binding, Japanese folding book method. You will also be inspired by creative and easy ways to capture your precious travel memories. By the end of the workshop, you will have created your own mini album/journal to bring along on your future travel adventures!
strTitle: Create a Mini Album - Capture Your Journey in Tokyo

strIntroduction: Kichijoij is conveniently located just 20mins away from Shinjuku and Shibuya station. There are plenty of fancy shops and funky people here. The lush and relaxing Inokashira Park also sits right beside this area. Kichijoji has been ranked number 1 "most popular place to live in Tokyo!" Come join us on a tour of the blind alleyways in Tokyo! Our guides speak fluent English, so you won't have to worry about a language barrier! First, we will arrange a customized journey for you based on what you what to experience. You can basically follow us around Kichijoji and see life as a local. We can visit the bustling blind alleys afterwards and visit the tranquil Inokashira Park. Stock up on snacks at the start of the trip! Next, you can choose from the following optional tours: -Eat Ramen noodle for lunch -Sit on a swan-shaped boat in Inokashira pond -Visit the famous Ghibli Museum -Relax at a famous public bath -Night pub crawl Some of these tours require advance reservation, so do book early to let us know Some Highlights of the tour: ■Hamonica yokocho - Great blind alley with local food and traditional bars. Good for shopping and pub crawls ■Inokashira park and temples - Walk around and relax over coffee at a fancy cafe. ■Benten-yu Public bath ■The Ghibli Museum - The most famous animation studio *Please book at least 2 weeks in advance if you would like to go on the Ghibli Tour. Here is a sample itinerary: 13:00: Meet at Kichijoji station 13:30: Go to Inokashira park. Take a picture with the traditional temples in the park 15:00: Take a short break at fancy forest cafe 15:30: Window shopping on Sun-Road street 16:00: Visit Hamonica-Yokocho bazaar 16:30: Walk around and buy popular snacks 17:00: Back to Kichijoji station Note that above itinerary is just a sample, and all of our tours are customized. Feel free ask us what you would like to do (what type of trip, duration, cost, food preferences)! We can arrange private tour just for you! There are many different and unique experiences available in Kichijoji, apart from typical tours that only bring you to famous places in Tokyo! I hope you won't miss this tour to enjoy the real Tokyo. We look forward to meeting you soon!
strTitle: Pop Round & Check Out the Best “Blind Alley” of Tokyo!
